Text.Line: Look at this city, it’s overcrowded, the air is filthy, and it’s terribly loud. Why would anyone want to live here?

DialogueOptions.AnswerText: Everyone has their preferences, but most people are here for work. Eventually, they get used to city life.
This may not look nice, but people here are still happy.
I agree, down with cities! We should all live in small villages.

Text.Line: Just because you can get used to a bad environment doesn’t make it a good thing.
As long as they are happy, I suppose there’s no problem.
My kind also lives only in small camps of 5-7 Zorgians.
Many people feel lonely in a big city, even though they’re surrounded by others. Why do you think that is?

DialogueOptions.AnswerText: People in cities are less likely to reach out and make contact.
They’re not lonely, just a bit tired.
Humans are social animals, but often afraid to start conversations with strangers.

Text.Line: Then you should build more recreational facilities.
I know the difference between loneliness and being tired.
You humans need to stop being so afraid of each other.
Look at that (H&M) clothing store. All those nice clothes, made through child labor. Why do people still buy them?

DialogueOptions.AnswerText: Most people don’t know much about it.
It’s cheap and easy to get, so people choose convenience over ethics.
Some people may want to do something, but they don’t know how to find alternatives.

Text.Line: I believe most people have heard about it at least once.
You feel nothing for others when you don't see or know them? Good to know.
On your own, you can’t do much.
Look at the high crime rate. Why would anyone want to live in a city where you could lose everything to thieves?

DialogueOptions.AnswerText: Not everyone gets robbed; many people live safely in the city.
That’s a good point, but there are ways to protect yourself, like security and neighborhood watch programs.
The crime rate is going down, which means cities are getting safer.

Text.Line: The fact that these things are even needed is disgusting.
